Award.AwardTitle: Beyond Marketing to Stealth Recruitment: Creating ICT Pathways from High School to College and Work for Underrepresented Groups

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Central California Coast region includes four community colleges that serve large numbers of rural, Latino/a and female students. However, few of these students receive training in computer and information technology fields, despite being in close proximity to the high-technology hubs of Silicon Valley and San Francisco.

This project will build technical education pathways that motivate and prepare rural, high school students from underrepresented groups to enter and stay on two information and communications technology (ICT) pathways: Networking, and Software and Systems Development.

The project will pilot test an approach that involves building strong, sustainable partnerships and infusing ICT skills into digital media high school classes using media computation and aligning them with college classes and workforce needs. This "stealth recruitment" approach is in contrast to most efforts that take a marketing approach that tries to convince students of the value of ICT classes; instead it leverages students? interests in digital media and contextualizes their learning. The approach will be developed and pilot tested by two community colleges, in partnership with high school teachers, employers, and intermediary organizations.

This intervention has the potential to contribute to our understanding of how to effectively bring together high school, community college, and industry representatives to build strong, sustainable partnerships and coherent pathways into ICT, and how to infuse deep ICT learning into digital media classes. The project will also determine whether a stealth marketing approach is effective for recruiting a more diverse student population into ICT courses and preparing and motivating them to meet workforce needs.

Te work is designed to address a shortage of US workers trained for a high-technology workforce by targeting students in CTE courses that are using computers but not already considering an ICT field. Other impacts include providing training, support, and resources for high school teachers in ICT, and for college faculty in recruiting and retaining underrepresented students. If effective, the project will result in a scalable strategy to increase the number and diversity of students, including those from rural settings, that consider and pursue ICT training and jobs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a shortage of US workers trained for the high-technology workforce and a need to build a pathway from K-12 to college and to tech careers. Secondary school educators are working in isolation to provide information and communications technologies (ICT) and digital media-related activities to their students, and they want to be connected to other K-12 educators and to college faculty. And community college faculty want more diversity in their computing courses. The goal of this project was to conduct a feasibility study to test two strategies designed to increase the number and diversity of rural students from underrepresented groups who aim to pursue ICT in community college courses, and in their careers.

There were three main objectives of this work: 1) to develop, test, and document a process for building strong and sustainable partnerships between high school and community college faculty that is connected to the needs and priorities of the regional high-tech industry, 2) to develop and test curricula modules in existing high school digital media classes to increase student motivation and preparation to pursue and persist in college courses and jobs in computing, and 3) to build the capacity of high school teachers to implement ICT activities and build the capacity of community college faculty to recruit underrepresented students into their ICT classes.

Intellectual Merit: The results contribute to knowledge about how to effectively bring together high school, community college, and industry representatives to build strong, sustainable partnerships and coherent pathways into ICT. They also advance our understanding of whether and how a "stealth recruitment" approach that infuses deep ICT learning into digital media classes can be effective for recruiting a more diverse student population into ICT courses and prepare them to meet workforce needs.

Broader Impacts: This project created a structured process and built partnerships across key stakeholders: community college faculty, high school teachers, tech industry representatives, and intermediaries. It produced Tip Sheets on how to start partnerships across these sectors, and created an online inventory of ICT and digital media educators and programs that is being used to build partnerships and leverage resources across two counties. The project also produced curriculum modules to introduce ICT to high school students in digital media classes, which attract students who are not currently thinking about ICT as a pathway, do not see the connection between what they are doing on the computer and ICT, and do not know how that pathway can positively impact the economics of their family and community. The modules were implemented with 128 high school students. An independent evaluation found that the students increased their knowledge of computer programming and computer-related careers, but not their interest in taking a range of computing-related classes.

The findings and products have been shared with local partners, including high school staff, teachers and administrators, community college faculty and administrators, and Regional Occupational Program teachers and administratores. They have also been shared nationally through social media, a blog post, and conference presentations.
